data.text: Contents
Pre Procedure Considerations (Including Indications for Testing) ........................ 6
Performance of an Adult Exercise Tolerance Test (ETT)/ 20016/ 1.0
Page  of
Introduction
Exercise tolerance testing (ETT) is a widely used tool which provides diagnostic and prognostic information for the evaluation of several pathologies, the most common being coronary artery disease.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

To provide guidance and support to all Cardiac Physiologists/Associate Practitioners performing and reporting an adult exercise test within Broomfield Hospital, to ensure that they can be performed in line with The Society of Cardiological Science and Technology (SCST) guidelines, ensuring consistency, continuity and safety during and between exercise testing.
Definitions

table_items.text: Society of Cardiological Science and Technology

data.text: Infection Prevention

All staff will adhere to Trust guidelines and policies on infection prevention at all times whilst performing an Exercise Tolerance Test, such as hand washing and the use of other infection prevention measures when required i.e. Gloves, aprons and effective decontamination of all non-disposable equipment between patients.
Staffing and Training
All medical staff are responsible for:
Being aware and compliant with this clinical guidance;
Ensuring they have adequate and appropriate training before performance of exercise testing;
Ensuring they are competent in the use of appropriate equipment and have completed competencies that document so: CS-185-002-14 (Refer to Appendix 1 for Core Competency);
Ensuring adequate information about the test is relayed to the patient and/or relative and verbal consent is gained prior to commencement of the Exercise Test;
Liaising with other members of the medical team if deemed appropriate regarding the results of the test.
Minimum staffing requirements for Adult Exercise Tolerance Testing (ETT) to be undertaken are as follows:
2 appropriately trained and competent personnel who hold up to date competencies in Intermediate Life Support (ILS).
If required an appropriately qualified physician – Dr Supervised ETT
Training responsibility will remain with the individual staff members and overall responsibility for wards/clinical areas with the Ward or Department Manager.
Environmental Considerations

The environment should be a well-lit, clean and well ventilated room. There must be enough space to accommodate all the necessary equipment, provide sufficient space for emergency and/or resuscitation procedures and be easily accessible for both able bodied patients and also the disabled where deemed safe to exercise.
The environment must be private and quiet to allow for privacy and dignity to be maintained at all times where reasonable possible i.e.: curtains/screens to be pulled.

The environment should allow where reasonable for possible adjustments to be made to ensure that hypersensitivities and sensory overload is accounted for those patients with Autism (Refer to ‘Caring for a young person /adult with autism in the acute setting'; register number 14010)

Immediate access to a suitable alarm system and/or telephone facilities must be readily available within the environment. Suction and oxygen should be available. Full resuscitation equipment should be kept within an acceptable distance to room where the exercise test is being performed. This must include a defibrillator. All equipment should be tested on a regular basis, with resuscitation equipment undergoing a check prior to each exercise test session.
Equipment
Minimum equipment requirements for Adult Exercise Tolerance Testing (ETT) to be undertaken are as follows:
CASE Treadmill or Exercise Bike;
Blood Pressure Monitor (Automatic or Manual);
CASE ECG Monitoring Machine;
Resuscitation Trolley, including defibrillator with pacing capability.
Pre Procedure Considerations (Including Indications for Testing)
Request forms will only be accepted from Cardiology Consultants working within the department. The following indications are generally accepted as reasons for an ETT being required:
Diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) in patient with chest pain that is atypical for myocardial ischemia;
Assessment of functional capacity and prognosis of patients with known CAD;
Assessment of prognosis and functional capacity of patients with CAD soon after uncomplicated myocardial infarction (before hospital discharge or early after discharge);
Evaluation of patient with symptoms consistent with recurrent, exercise-induced cardiac arrhythmias;
Assessment of functional capacity of selected patients with congenital or valvular heart disease;
Evaluation of patients with rate-response pacemakers;
Evaluation of asymptomatic men >40 years with special occupations (Airline pilots, bus drivers, etc.);
Evaluation of asymptomatic individuals >40 years with two or more risk factors for CAD;
Evaluation of sedentary individuals (men >45 years and women >55 years) with two or more risk factors who plan to enter a vigorous exercise program;
Assessment of function capacity and response to therapy in patients with ischemic heart disease or hear failure;
Monitoring progress and safety in conjunction with rehabilitation after a cardiac event or surgical procedure.

Arrangements for immediate clinical consultation and assistance should be clearly defined prior to testing. Should it be deemed necessary for an ETT to be supervised by a doctor, this should be clearly marked on the request form and arrangements should be made prior to the test date.
Clinical notes should be requested by the Cardiac Co-ordinator prior to the test date to ensure they are available on the day of testing.

Two appropriately trained and competent personnel must be available for safe supervision and management of ETT. Both suitably qualified healthcare professionals must be present during both the exercise and recovery stages of the ETT. The supervisor is responsible for safe conduct during the ETT and should hold an appropriate degree for example Clinical Physiology (Cardiac) that incorporates the underpinning knowledge relating to exercise testing. They should have extensive experience with ETT and be fully competent in the use of all equipment. The supervisor can postpone the investigation if they believe that it cannot be conducted appropriately or safely. The assisting roll requires in-house ETT training to meet requirements in order to assist with ETT. Responsibilities of the assisting
role are preparation of environment and patient and to provide assistance during exercise and recovery.

Screening for pilots, LGV and PCV license applicants must only be supervised by staff familiar with the requirements of the Driver Licensing Vehicle Authority (DVLA). These tests should be carried out as private procedures due to the associated fees that accompany, please refer to the Private Patient Policy – register number 12024).
Contraindications for Testing
The contraindications to low risk ETT are listed below:
Severe angina or worsening rest angina;
Angina which is < 1 month post MI, post PTCA/Stent, post CABG;
Known Left Main Stem (LMS) Disease;
Uncontrolled Raise BP (Systolic >180mmHg and/or Diastolic >100mmHg);
Hypotension (Systolic BP <90mmHg);
History of Sustained Ventricular Arrhythmias;

Repolarisation abnormalities that prevent ST analysis, for example Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) – unless test is requested for arrhythmia provocation only or to assess chronotropic response to exercise;
Significant aortic stenosis;
Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM);
Screening test for Pilots, LGV, PCV licensing when the physiologist is unfamiliar
with the requirements for the licensing authority.

This list is not exhaustive and as such staff should be aware that other contra- indications may exist. Requests that meet any of the contra-indication to a low risk ETT are therefore classified as high risk and in these instances require discussion with the requesting consultant to ensure that the correct medical supervision is provided if the test is to be performed.
Patient Preparation

Patients should receive an appointment letter prior to testing. This should contain a brief description of the procedure along with details regarding clothing, drugs and food. On arrival to the test patients should be introduced to all the staff that will be present during the ETT. The patient's identifiable information should be confirmed. This includes name, date of birth and hospital number. Both test purpose and test procedure should be fully explained in detail to the patient. Explanation should cover the level of undress involved along with the use of adhesive electrodes. There should be adequate time allowed for the patient to become familiarised with the test equipment.

Importance of reporting any symptoms felt during the test should be explained to the patient. The patient should also be made aware that stopping while the treadmill is in motion brings about a safety risk and therefore any wish to stop should be communicated with the team so that terminating the test can be done in a safe manner.

Completed request form and notes must be present. A clinical history should be performed with the emphasis on excluding any specific contraindication and confirming suitability for the investigation. Confirmation that the patient has followed any medication instructions should be established.

Every effort should be made to provide privacy and maintain patient dignity. A gown should be supplied where necessary with front fastening to allow for electrode adjustment if required. Skin preparation is required to minimise interference between electrode and skin. Areas should be shaved where required and an alcohol based substance designed for skin use should be used. Razors should be immediately deposed of in a sharps bin. Care should be taken with patients who have delicate, sensitive or broken skin. A standard 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) electrode placement cannot be obtained during ETT and therefore a modification of the standard 12-lead ECG is required.
In summary:
Chest electodes – As per standard 12-lead ECG electrode placement (Refer to ‘Performance of an Adult 12 Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG)' ; register number 16009)
Right arm electrode – upper right side of torso
Left arm electrode – upper leftt side of torso
Right leg electorde – lower right side of torso, half way between costal margin and iliac crest
Left leg electorde – lower left side of torso, half way between costal margin and
iliac crest
Figure 1- Correct ECG placement for ETT - https://nasiff.com/help/fig1.htm

data.url: 20016 Performance of an Adult Exercise Tolerance Test 1.0.003.png

data.text: Exercise Tolerance Testing Requirements

ECG and blood pressure (BP) measurements are obtained before the start of the ETT. The test should be performed in line with the Bruce protocol. The modified Bruce protocol can be used when deemed necessary for patients with limitations in mobility. Protocols may be adapted in instances such as donor work ups and testing for DVLA requirements.

There must be continuous monitoring of ECG, heart rate and BP throughout the entirety of the test. BP should be taken at rest, immediately before progression into the next stage of exercise, at peak exercise and at intervals during recovery until return to an acceptable resting level.
Tests are symptom limited, maximal or terminated due to a test end point being reached. These include:
Technical difficulties with monitoring of ECG or BP;
Symptoms such as dizziness or near syncope;
Signs of poor perfusion;
Exercise induced arrhythmia;
Rapid ST elevation with or without pain;
SBP falling >20 mmHg;
>3mm ST depression without symptoms;
>2mm ST elevation with symptoms;
SBP rise >230 mmHg;
Severe chest pain or shortness of breath;
Heart rate falling by >20% of starting rate;
Unsteadiness of gait;
Predicted maximal heart rate maintained for 1 minute;
Development of bundle branch block;
Upon patient request to stop.

In the occurrence of an adverse event, the treadmill should be stopped immediately, the emergency buttons should be activated if appropriate and help sort. BLS and ILS protocols should be followed when required. CPR should be to current resuscitation council (UK) guidelines. It is the responsibility of the supervisor to manage the incident until more expert help arrives.

Recovery of the ETT is designed to ensure physiological measurements have returned to or near to baseline conditions, to monitor symptoms and to monitor ECG changes. Recovery should last for a minimum of 6 minutes after exercise termination.
Exercise Tolerance Testing Reporting

A standard report should be produced and forwarded onto the requesting consultant. Highly abnormal test results or results highlighting a significant finding which could impact the patients' health should be flagged to the referring consultant/ on call registrar prior to the patient leaving the department.
A technical report outlining the following should be included as a minimum:
Protocol used i.e. Bruce protocol;
Resting ECG appearance;
Total exercise time/stage achieved;
Percentage of predicted maximum heart rate achieved;
Reason for termination;
BP/HR response to exercise;
Significant events, including initial occurrence, when it reached a peak and when it resolved i.e. chest pain;
ST changes, including measurements in mm and in which lead changes occurred;
Symptoms during test. What, when, association with other abnormalities;
Arrhythmias.

The recommendations presented in this document are intended for the use in any environment where adult ETT is required. These recommendations are not intended to apply for paediatric exercise testing.
Monitoring and Audit
Compliance will be audited through training records in line with local trust learning and development policies and CPD records.
Adherence to this guidance will be monitored by review of reported incidents and complaints via the Datix system. These will be dealt with by the relevant head of department/ward.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be circulated clinically and professional approval confirmed by the Asset Owner prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform appropriate staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranet.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 2)
References
CS-185-002-14 - GE CASE IT and Treadmill (Clinical Competency)

Society of Cardiological Science and Technology (SCST) (March 2008), ‘Clinical Guidelines by Consensus, Recommendations for Clinical Exercise Testing' [Online] Available at: http://www.scst.org.uk/resources/ETT_consensus_March_2008.pdf

Worcestershire Acute Hospitals NHS Trust (May 2014) ‘Exercise Testing Procedure (Reference document for Cardiac Physiologist)' [Online] Available at: http://www2.worcsacute.nhs.uk/EasysiteWeb/getresource.axd?AssetID- 46080&type=full&servicetype=Attachment
Appendix 1: CS-185-002-14 Clinical Competency
MEDICAL DEVICE / EQUIPMENT COMPETENCY SELF ASSESSMENT STATEMENT

table_items.text: Areas where equipment used: Cardiac Department-Outpatients A210
Complex Intermediate Basic External / DCCT DCCT / Super-user Self/ Peer

data.text: The statements below are designed to assess your competence to use this device. You should self-assess your competency after you have received the relevant training. Responsibility for use of the equipment remains with you, so if you are in any doubt about your competence to use the device, you must seek additional training in liaison with your line manager / supervisor and then re-assess your competence against the statement. Sources of training support include the product operating manual and training from peers, super-users or Clinical Technicians as appropriate.

table_items.text: Questions to ask yourself: Are you safe using this equipment? Do you know the following?
Turn the ECG machine and treadmill on and off
Select patient record or enter a new patient record
Add relevant patient information (consultant, medications, test reason etc)
Select appropriate protocol from ‘protocol editor tab'
Provide a brief explanation of ‘Function keypad' on ECG machine (including adding comments)
Demonstrate manual adjustment of stages (speed and incline)
Print off resting ECG prior to exercise commencing
Enter a manual blood pressure reading
Demonstrate ending test and printing off test summary
Demonstrate completion of technical report and print
Demonstrate retrospective printing of rhythm strips/ECGs
Show location of emergency stop button and demonstrate it's use
Show location of treadmill reset button
Printing off a previously completed report with ECG tracings

data.text: You must be able to answer yes to all questions relevant to your role to consider yourself competent. If you are competent, you should date and sign your Diagnostic & Therapeutic Equipment Competency Record for this equipment. If you are not competent, please identify this on your record, signing and dating the record appropriately, and discuss with your manager how and when your training needs will be met.
Your line manager should retain your Diagnostic & Therapeutic Equipment Competency Record. Self - assessment is undertaken on a one-off basis but will be reviewed annually at appraisal.
